content.description:
Start same as Prow left or Sharks Tooth left? names are unclear, campus to jug in seam and mantle the lip, great mantle practice.

 One pad is all you need.
content.location: Prow boulder, left side.

content.description:
Around the left side of the main boulder are several V-Easy warm up boulder problems. Decent enough to warm up on and great for the novice climber looking to get a feel for Acadia National Park stone.  

  The back side of the Canada Cliffs Main Boulder has a couple V0- problems as well, the perfect warm up to check if the rock is dry and climbable, or for beginners, etc. Fun, easy, straight forward climbs with relatively safe landings as well.
content.location: Main boulder, around the left side of the left arete.

content.description:
Right around the corner from "The Prow," aka 'Lip Traverse Right,' aka 'Shark Tooth (right).'  

  Start all the way at the bottom of the sloping slab at left, making your way from left-to-right up the obvious line on the corner, topping-out in the middle. (There's a variation that starts directly in the middle and finishes at the same spot that goes at V2-). 

  Here is a short edit featuring this line and more. I've worked hard over the past few years establishing and repeating some of these stellar lines in Acadia National Park, making sure to document much of the climbing on video and paper. Please enjoy: youtube.com/watch?v=Z7N7YUA…
content.location: Up the hill from "The Prow," aka the Lip Traverse.

content.description:
Unknown slab up the hill from the main boulder. This is a very fun and well protected line, though quite heady due to a tree in part of the landing and it being a slab. 

  Here is a short video edit made for these areas and more: 

youtube.com/watch?v=Z7N7YUA…

  Thank you, enjoy your time in Acadia.
content.location: Directly up the hill and to the right of the Main Canada Cliffs Boulder.

content.description:
On the leftmost side of the "Steal Once, Pay Twice" boulder, this was first established by local, Jonathan Hogue.  

  An awkward start down low leads to better climbing up high towards the lip, though the grade is given for the lowest possible start. Start crimped on terrible starting holds and move up and left to a side-pull and a jug, then one big move to the lip (short and sweet), but fun none-the-less.
content.location: Follow the directions to "Steal Once, Pay Twice," and it's on the left side of the boulder as you walk up the hill towards "Old World Underground."

content.description:
First established by Jonathan Hogue in 2016, this boulder problem was always on the local boulderers radar, but cleaning and prepping the problem took several days due to heavy liken and moss that impeded the line. After much work hanging in a harness for days on end, Jonathan put up the FA and named it "Steal Once, Pay Twice," a beautiful problem on incut crimps from start to finish! 

  Sit start with high hands on the obvious jugs. Delicately move up the middle of the boulder on incut crimps and decent feet. It's quite tall and the landing slopes downwards (stepped down), so crash-pads and spotters are recommended. 

  Here is a short edit featuring this line and more where we've established and repeated some of these stellar lines: youtube.com/watch?v=Z7N7YUA…
content.location: From the wooden stairs at the start of the Canada Cliffs Trail-Head, follow the hiking trail all the way back towards the woods, perhaps a half mile from the parking lot. When the trail splits left towards the service road, stay right, and start following the pathway up the hill continuing on the Canada Cliffs Trail. The boulder will be visible in the woods to the right, it's hard to miss because it's HUGE!

content.description: Hard face between Mammoth and Irish Goodbye. Start on a crimp rail and climb up with long moves on not so good holds.
content.location: Between Mammoth and Irish Goodbye.

content.description:
On the back side of the boulder featuring, "Steal Once, Pay Twice."  

  Sit start very low on a razor sharp under-cling with your left hand, and decent right hand crimp/pinch sort of hold. Move up and right on obvious incut crimps, (all of which are quite sharp in nature), and finish directly up the arete on the rightmost side.   

  The start is hard for the grade. Stand start is maybe V0-, but due to the awkward sit start on terrible smears (and often times damp feet), it was decided to put a V3 grade on it which has been the general consensus since development. 

  Fun, short; packs a punch!
content.location: "Steal Once, Pay Twice" boulder on the backside up the hill.

content.description: Sit start low on the left side of the boulder. Start holds are the two slots at the beginning of the crack wide enough for fingers. Work your way a few moves along the crack to the arete, then straight up for an easy top out.
content.protection: Good landing. One pad is enough.
content.location: About 100ft along the Canada Cliffs trail, the boulder is to the right a few yards off the path. It has a very large and noticeable crack down the middle on the side facing the trail and a small tree on top.

content.description:
The massive line on the highball boulder visibly to the left of the Canada Cliffs Main Boulder. This thing is tall and insanely proud. The landing is terrible as well, so come prepared. (30 ft. maybe?!) 

  The top out is terribly hard. Mantle for your life!  

  Also, make sure to scope it out and clean it before attempting, as many injuries from ground falls have been reported from this boulder. I myself landed, bouncing off the tree to the ground, and was lucky not to have broken my legs.
content.protection: Pads. Some people may wish for spotter(s) .
content.location: The huge boulder to the left of the Canada Cliffs Main Boulder. Can't miss it!

climbs.name: Lip Traverse Right, Shark Tooth Boulder

content.description: Sit start on large chalked hold. Climb out the arete/lip with good tension to cool pinches and a big move to jugs. Mantle. Super good problem!
content.location: Pass the Main Boulder on your left. Continue on the faint climbers trail with the boulders on your left until you see a triangular overhung face on a medium block. A short minute of walking. See photos.

climbs.name: Lip Traverse Left, Shark Tooth Boulder

content.description: Stand start with left hand edge and right hand undercling. Traverse right with funky moves and finish up at the jugs. This thing would be quite a bit easier if the tree wasn’t there, so some funky core tension has to be used or else you’ll just dab the tree. Rad climbing!
content.location: Canada cliffs. Follow the faint climbers trail from the hiking trail entrance with wooden stairs and head directly up the hill towards the visible boulders. Hike right past the first "main boulder" and continue heading into the woods until the triangular boulder is found a quarter mile up the hill from the main area.

content.description:
[NOTE: Apparently the same climb as "Prow" and or "Shark's Tooth right". RHall Admin.]

 Coarse rock, stand start on right side of overhanging triangular boulder, and traverse the lip, topping out at the point. 

  The "Lip Traverse" (right), is a V4 stand start.   There's also a sit start on decent incut crimps, with a heinous heel hook at the beginning.   It is the consensus among locals that the sit start (lowest possible start on the right), definitely adds a number grade to this problem V5 to V5+.
content.location: Take the stairs near the bus turn around at the entrance to the parking lot for Echo Lake. Head straight up to the visible boulders as a point of reference. For this climb, go farther up to the right about 100 yards, passing a smaller overhanging triangular roof and proceeding to the larger one.

content.description: Sit start low on the leftmost side of the boulder. Work your way up the arete, slapping up the sloping edges and incut crimps to a tricky mantle.
content.location: Canada Cliffs wooded area.

climbs.name: Its Never Pretty aka Grovel Time

content.description:
This is the roof problem to the right of the obvious slab.  

  Sit start low and left on a small crimp edge. Make dynamic moves up and right, finishing directly up the arete on good holds.  

  The crux is groveling over the roof onto the arete off of terrible edges and slopers. If you're taller it makes it easier, but this little problem can be defeating.
content.location: Triangular boulder up the hill and to the right of the main boulder at Canada Cliffs, up the hill from the Canada Cliffs Trail-Head.

content.description: Climb the arete with really bad holds and big moves. I’ve not tried this but Keenan said it felt like hard 11 and it was a really good line. It looks cool anyway.
content.protection: Pads and maybe a spotter. It’s sort of tall
content.location: The right arete on the Mammoth boulder. Pretty obvious

content.description: Sit start on an obvious left hand crimp and a right hand Gaston, a weird lung/lock-off move gets you into the good edge.
content.location: Right of main crack

content.description: Start on large in-cut hold on right side of face. Make a big but easy move to a pinch/crimp then go up from there. Sort of contrived, as there is an easier variation just right, but this is a nice problem.
content.protection: Crash-pads and spotter may be helpful. Be mindful of the pointy rocks inhabiting the landing.  Injuries have been recorded, though it looks totally safe.
content.location: Main boulder, right side.

content.description:
The right side of the main boulder, stand start at an obvious incut crimp and make a big move out right side to the lip. Traverse back left to top-out mantel. 

 Here is a short edit featuring this line and more. I've worked hard over the past few years establishing and repeating some of these stellar lines in Acadia National Park, making sure to document much of the climbing on video and paper. Please enjoy: youtube.com/watch?v=Z7N7YUA…
content.location: Main boulder Canada Cliffs.

content.description: Start as for Center Crack Sit and move right to the start hold of Dyno-Soar once you get your left hand to the crescent right hand start crimp for Center Crack Stand. Then finish up Dyno-Soar. The crux revolves around getting your left hand on the crescent start hold for the stand (harder than it looks) and moving off of it.
content.protection: 2 pads. It's a bit of a traverse
content.location: Start as for center crack sit on the Canada Cliff Main Boulder

content.description: Stand start at obvious right hand crimp and left hand pod in crack. Make a few hard moves before reaching easier moves then the top out.
content.location: Canada Cliffs Main Boulder Center.

content.description: The sit to the crack/seam. Hard moves on really small pods lead to the stand, which is more hard moves on small pods. Cool looking line but it’s kind of sharp and odd climbing.
content.protection: A pad or two is fine. Good landing
content.location: Obvious crack on main boulder.

content.description: These are the boulder climbs around Canada Cliff
